channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald articles
channel.description: Latest comment articles. For all the articles, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: Michael Sam: The (gay) eagle has landed
item.description: At the beginning of their season late last year, American college football star Michael Sam told his teammates something that would make history.

item.title: Enough kowtowing - time to ban the bomb
item.description: Even by the horrible metrics of war, the detonation of a nuclear warhead on Hiroshima in 1945 saw destruction of human life, and of the city itself, on a scale previously unimaginable.

item.title: A positive approach to an entrenched problem
item.description: By accepting the inevitability of some unemployment we can focus on engaging the jobless.

item.title: Tony Abbott's economic wounds are self-inflicted
item.description: The economic troubles afflicting the Abbott government are all self-inflicted.

item.title: No jumper leads, please, for our car industry
item.description: Protectionism is like sin: we're opposed to it, but we succumb to it every now and again.

item.title: We must engage, not enrage nuclear countries
item.description: This week, representatives from around the world, including Australia, are meeting at a conference in Mexico to discuss the humanitarian impact of nuclear weapons.

item.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock is our Valentine's Day story
item.description: Since the publication of Picnic at Hanging Rock in 1967, Joan Lindsay's haunting story about the disappearance of three students and a teacher on St Valentine's Day 1900 has captured the imaginations of successive generations.

item.title: In the Herald: February 14, 1880
item.description: A brightening of the weather brought ''a refreshing activity'' to the Garden Palace. In the German Court, Madame Summerhayes gave a recital on the Bechstein Grand, playing Thalberg's Home, Sweet Home, and other pieces.

item.title: Mum's boyfriend - the worst sexual risk to children
item.description: Research shows that 'stranger danger' is a rule that must apply at home, too.

item.title: Dominant ABC hurting the commercial sector
item.description: The national broadcaster is having a devastating impact on rival media projects because it has the advantage of public funding.

item.title: Heydon royal commission into unions aims for jackpot
item.description: Throughout the nation lawyers gasped as they tried to absorb the pages of print that spell out the terms of reference for the Royal Commission into Rotten Unions and their Connection to the ALP.

item.title: Palmer and Swan in the desert, not quite Burke and Wills
item.description: A Clive Palmer press club appearance is one part performance art, one part circus and two parts a gentle frolic through a parkland of conspiracy theories.

item.title: Toyota catches Canberra napping
item.description: Promising that workers will go to better jobs will be a hard thing to deliver.

item.title: Government being caught by surprise does not augur well for providing laid-off workers with better jobs
item.description: Tony Abbott says Toyota's manufacturing workers will graduate ''from good jobs to better jobs''.

item.title: Labor left out in the cold
item.description: Having lost its compass, the ALP faces a long stretch in the political wilderness - and even its allies look lost.

item.title: Bill Shorten hamstrung by union ties
item.description: Bill Shorten dominated the first day of Parliament of 2014. He dominated question time. He asked all eight questions allotted to the opposition. The first seven questions were about Toyota shutting down its manufacturing in Australia. Shorten also dominated the second day, asking question after question.

item.title: PM shows the meaning of 'fair go'
item.description: Tony Abbott is brave to tackle crucial reform of workplace relations.

item.title: Toyota catches Canberra napping
item.description: Promising that workers will go to better jobs will be a hard thing to deliver.

item.title: Battle of the fittest in Abbott's pure world
item.description: Businesses and the unemployed are not spared in the government's tough stance on the economy.

item.title: The Beatles: Subversion that's lasted for decades
item.description: The conventional wisdom that the Beatles were cute is ridiculous.

item.title: If only the world boasted more uppity women
item.description: History is seldom kind to clever women. I do not hold with the postmodern revisionism that turns every great man's wife, aunt, sister or daughter into the true behind-throne power. That just validates the veil. But a new retrospective of an obscure artist at a small London gallery makes me wonder, again, how different history might be if smart women spoke.

item.title: Hillary Clinton's popularity serves as red flag to US hatred industry
item.description: Reaction to a trove of documents reveals much about how some Republicans plan to tackle a Clinton White House bid.

item.title: Aunty got burnt by mangling the message
item.description: Coalition resentment about the national broadcaster has simmered for years.

item.title: The pope's Catholic problem
item.description: It's not easy being pope. You have 2000 years of tradition to defend. You have piles of doctrine and an ecclesiastical bureaucracy. Meanwhile, you have liberals clamouring for change. And then there's your boss.

item.title: Schapelle Corby, Rachelle Louise, the Harnum family: Seven's grubby week of chequebook journalism
item.description: True crime pays. The Seven Network's shareholders had better believe it.
